CV/Resume





Katharine L. Leigh
Santa Barbara, CA | 925-212-6065 | kleigh@bren.ucsb.edu | https://twitter.com/SmallScaleOA

Education

University of California Santa Barbara, Bren School of Environmental Science & Management
Master of Environmental Science and Management
Expected 2021
GPA: 3.82
Specialization: Coastal Marine Resources Management
Foci: Eco-Entrepreneurship & Data Science


Cornell University, College of Agriculture and Life Sciences (CALS)
Bachelor of Science in Biology
15-May
GPA: 3.53
Concentration: Marine
Awards: Cum Laude; Distinction in Research; Morris & Stewart Udall Scholarship


National University of Singapore, Study Abroad
Spring 2014
GPA: 3.5
Awards: Benjamin A. Gilman International Scholarship



Aquatic Research & Implementation Experience

Karang (formerly SmallScaleOceanAction)
Designer, Founder, & CEO
Aug. 2014 - Present California, Indonesia, & the Philippines
A digital platform that can enable information flow and automates collaboration among coastal information Providers and Users by leveraging supply and demand within a decentralized network.
Initially investigating use-cases specific to blast fishing prevention; aquatic monitoring; and collective algorithm development in select coastal communities.


Environmental Defense Fund
Fisheries Climate Modeling and Blast Fishing Prevention Intern
Jun. 2020 - Present California
Developing a semi-quantitative, spatially-specific model to predict changes in fishery production for Indonesian Blue Swimming Crab that accounts for climate variables and biological life stages.
Investigating commonalities, differences, enabling factors, and potential solutions to blast fishing in several countries through literature reviews and interviews with experts and on-the-ground practitioners.
Fisheries Economic Modeling Masters Group Project
Mar. 2020 - Present California
Developing a theoretical framework and R-coded model for quota baskets: https://www.fishwallet.net/.
Model is parameterized by empirical data from various Chinese fisheries.
Fisheries Management Consultant
Oct. 2015 - Dec. 2015 California & Indonesia
Produced a report on the Indonesian Pole-Caught and Hook-and-Line Caught Tuna Fishery, with a focus on skipjack and yellowfin. Included a stakeholder analysis and relationship diagram of cooperatives, NGOs, fisheries management organizations, and branches of the Indonesian government.


The Nature Conservancy
Specialist, Palmyra/Global Science/Indo-Pacific Tuna Programs
Jan. 2018 - Aug. 2019 Virginia
Developed and implemented the Palmyra Program open-access data management strategy which recently received $ 20,000 gift from a private donor.
Developed internal and external documents for and represented the Indonesian Deepwater Snapper Grouper Fishery Improvement Project at public-facing events.
CODA Fellow, Palmyra Program
Feb. 2018 - Dec. 2018 Virginia
Analyzed the feasibility a proposed collaborative Pacific island/ocean science initiative.
Developed the initiative statement of purpose within the Science for Nature and People Partnership.
Fisheries Management Consultant
Aug. 2015 - Oct. 2015 California
Reported and presented on the role of uncertainty within fishery council management and decision-making, emphasizing the Pacific Fisheries Management Council.
Promoted the California Ground Fish Collective, and their pooled catch-shares/eCatch program.


NMSF

            Kat Leigh
          
          
            
              I’m a Cornell University alumnus, and current second-year Masters student at the Bren School of Environmental Science & Management at the University of California Santa Barbara. Prior to Bren, I worked for The Nature Conservancy, Environmental Defense Fund, Cornell University, and Epic Software Systems in positions including project management and implementation, marketing, collaborative science development, public data accessibility, and community-based fisheries management. Recently, I came to Bren to hone my marine ecology skills, as well as focus on launching my business idea, Karang, a digital network that enables information flow for coastal communities and the seafood industry. After Bren, I hope to pursue an economics PhD to investigate some of the complexities of Karang. Ultimately, I aim to use Karang to shift the incentives operating in the blue economy to support efficient, equitable, and truly sustainable management of aquatic resources.
